Postdoctoral Associate
Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences
Center on Aging

1695 NW 9th Ave
Suite 3208D
Miami, FL 33136
Email: rxb285@med.miami.edu
Twitter: @RonBerkowsky
EDUCATION
PhD in Medical Sociology
University of Alabama at Birmingham
Birmingham, AL
Dissertation: Internet Use and Mental Health/Well-Being in Old Age:
Exploring the Roles of Social Integration and Social Support
MA in Sociology
University of Alabama at Birmingham
Birmingham, AL
Thesis: Internet Use, Social Integration, and Psychological Well-Being in
Older Adults
Certificate in Gerontology, Gerontology Education Program
University of Alabama at Birmingham
Birmingham, AL
BA in Health and Societies
University of Pennsylvania
Philadelphia, PA
University of Miami Miller School of Medicine
Postdoctoral Associate: Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences –
Center on Aging
Description: Postdoctoral research conducted through the University of Miami
Center on Aging. Currently consults with the Scientific Director Sara Czaja
primarily on the Center for Research and Education on Aging and Technology
Enhancement (CREATE), a multidisciplinary and collaborative center
dedicated to investigating the trends and benefits of technology use among
older adults. Supervisor: Dr. Sara Czaja.
RESEARCH/WORK EXPERIENCE
2014 – present
RESEARCH/WORK EXPERIENCE (CONTINUED)
University of Alabama at Birmingham Department of Sociology
Graduate Research Assistant: Mid-South Transdisciplinary Collaborative
Center for Health Disparities Research - Social Determinants of Health
Measurement (SDHM) Core
Description: NIH-funded project focused on reducing chronic disease burden
of African-Americans in Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi. SDHM Core
focused on providing theoretical and methodological expertise regarding SDH
as well as measurement and data tools. Research responsibilities included (but
were not limited to): creating and maintaining research bank/toolbox with
SDH measures and finding and evaluating SDH data. Supervisor: Dr. William
Cockerham.
University of Alabama at Birmingham Department of Sociology
Project Coordinator: Work-Life and Technology Use Study
Description: Online survey study focused on examining the relationship
between technology use and stress/spillover in the US working population.
Primary responsibilities were to oversee and manage research team during the
construction and implementation of the online survey as well as to provide
assistance during data cleaning and analysis. PI: Dr. Shelia Cotten.
University of Alabama at Birmingham Department of Sociology
Graduate Research Assistant: UAB ICTs and Quality of Life Study
Description: NIA-funded project focused on exploring the impacts of computer
and Internet use on older adults residing in assisted and independent living
communities. Research responsibilities included (but were not limited to):
participant recruitment/consent, survey scheduling and administration,
technological intervention instruction (lead), activity-control intervention
participation (assistant), data cleaning/analysis, and manuscript preparation
(lead author, co-author, reviewer). PI: Dr. Shelia Cotten.
University of Pennsylvania Health System
Clinical Research Coordinator: Division of Gastroenterology
Description: Worked on a number of clinical investigations conducted at the
University of Pennsylvania Hospital as well as at Penn Presbyterian Hospital.
Role was primarily administrative, although some lab work was required.
Responsibilities included (but were not limited to): IRB/HIPAA certification
and adherence, participant recruitment/consent, and limited sample collection
and analysis. Supervisor: Dr. James Lewis.
University of Pennsylvania Department of Sociology
Undergraduate Research Assistant: Population Studies Center
Description: Worked on a number of sociology/demography studies for the
department of sociology. Responsibilities included (but were not limited to):
data collection (quantitative and qualitative), data organization/cleaning,
and assorted clerical tasks. Supervisor: Dr. Irma Elo.
PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT
Op-Ed Pieces and Pitches: Framing Research for Public Audiences
CUNY Graduate School of Journalism
August 8
Description: Workshop hosted by JustPublics@365 on strategies used to
disseminate scholarly research to the public via op-ed pieces, essays, and
interviews. Held as a pre-conference workshop to the 2013 meeting of the
American Sociological Association.
Summer Social Webshop
University of Maryland
August 20-24
Description: Intensive workshop on Technology-Mediated Social Participation
(TMSP); topics covered include Internet and society, social media, information
visualization, network analysis, collective action, user interface design, Health
2.0, policy/privacy/identity, and research methodology. Granted $1,300
honorarium from University of Maryland to attend.
PUBLICATIONS – JOURNAL ARTICLES
Sharit, Joseph, Jessica Taha, Ronald W. Berkowsky, Halley Profita, and Sara J. Czaja. 2015. “Online
Information Search Performance and Search Strategies in a Health Problem Solving Scenario.”
Journal of Cognitive Engineering and Decision Making (published online ahead of print). doi:
Winstead, Vicki, Elizabeth A. Yost, Shelia R. Cotten, Ronald W. Berkowsky, and William A.
Anderson. 2014. “The Impact of Activity Interventions on the Well-Being of Older Adults in
Continuing Care Communities.” Journal of Applied Gerontology 33(7): 888-911. doi:
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2013. “When You Just Cannot Get Away: Exploring the Use of Information
and Communication Technologies in Facilitating Negative Work/Home Spillover.” Information,
Berkowsky, Ronald W., Shelia R. Cotten, Elizabeth A. Yost, and Vicki P. Winstead. 2013. “Attitudes
Towards and Limitations to ICT Use in Assisted and Independent Living Communities: Findings
from a Specially-Designed Technological Intervention.” Educational Gerontology 39(11): 797-
Winstead, Vicki, William A. Anderson, Elizabeth A. Yost, Shelia R. Cotten, Amanda Warr, and Ronald
W. Berkowsky. 2013. “You Can Teach an Old Dog New Tricks: A Qualitative Analysis of How
Residents of Senior Living Communities May Use the Web to Overcome Spatial and Social
Barriers.” Journal of Applied Gerontology 32(5): 540-560. doi: 10.1177/0733464811431824.
PUBLICATIONS – BOOK CHAPTERS
Berkowsky, Ronald W., RV Rikard, and Shelia Cotten. 2015. “Signing Off: Predicting Discontinued
ICT Usage among Older Adults in Assisted and Independent Living – A Survival Analysis.” In
Human Aspects of IT for the Aged Population. Design for Everyday Life, edited by J. Zhou and G.
Salvendy. Switzerland: Springer International Publishing. doi: 10.1007/978-3-319-20913-5_36.
PUBLICATIONS - OTHER
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2014. “Aging and Stress.” In The Wiley-Blackwell Encyclopedia of Health,
Illness, Behavior, and Society. Blackwell Publishing. doi: 10.1002/9781118410868.wbehibs020.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2014. “ICT and Stress.” In The Wiley-Blackwell Encyclopedia of Health,
Illness, Behavior, and Society. Blackwell Publishing. doi: 10.1002/9781118410868.wbehibs425.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2014. “Stress Across the Life Course.” In The Wiley-Blackwell
Encyclopedia of Health, Illness, Behavior, and Society. Blackwell Publishing. doi:
IN PRESS
Berkowsky, Ronald W. and Sara J. Czaja. “The Use of Technology in Behavioral Intervention
Research: Advantages and Challenges.” In Behavioral Intervention Research: Designing,
Evaluating, and Implementing, edited by L.N. Gitlin and S.J. Czaja. New York: Springer.
Elizabeth Yost, Vicki Winstead, Ronald W. Berkowsky, and Shelia R. Cotten. “Googling Grannies:
How Technology Use Can Improve Health and Well-Being in Aging Populations.” In Digital
Media Usage Across the Lifecourse, edited by P.G. Nixon, R. Rawal, and A. Funk. Surrey, UK:
Ashgate.
WORKS IN PROGRESS
Designing Technology Training for Older Adults in Continuing Care Retirement Communities. Book
manuscript under contract with CRC Press of Taylor and Francis. Written with Shelia R. Cotten,
Elizabeth A Yost, Vicki Winstead, and William A. Anderson.
“The Impact of Activities on Social Support among Older Adults in Independent and Assisted Living
Facilities.”
“The Interaction between Internet Use and Functional Limitations in Predicting Depressive
Symptoms in Older Adults.” Based on PhD dissertation research.
“Internet Use, Social Integration, and Psychological Well-Being in Older Adults.” Based on MA
thesis research.
GRANTS – PROPOSALS UNDER REVIEW
Berkowsky, Ronald W. (PI) and Sara J. Czaja. 2015. “Transitioning to Assisted Living Study
(TALS): Qualitative Assessment of the Challenges Facing Older Adults and Their Families.” R03
proposal submitted for review to the National Institutes of Health, June 16.
Work and Retirement
Mental Health
eHealth
Aging/Social Gerontology
Social Impacts of Technology
RESEARCH INTERESTS
Medical Sociology
CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS
Berkowsky, Ronald W., Sara J. Czaja, Joseph Sharit, Sankaran N. Nair, and Vicki Hanson. 2015.
“Age, Culture, and Digital Literacy: Examining Differences in Trust in eHealth Websites.”
Accepted to the annual meeting of the Gerontological Society of America, November 18-22,
Orlando, FL.
Yost, Elizabeth, Ronald W. Berkowsky, Vicki Winstead, and Shelia R. Cotten. 2015. “Not Alone:
Examining the Effects of Different Types of Activities on Social Support among Residents of

Berkowsky, Ronald W., RV Rikard, and Shelia Cotten. 2015. “Signing Off: Predicting Discontinued

Presented at the 1st International Conference on Human Aspects of IT for the Aged Population

Angeles, CA.
Cotten, Shelia R., Ronald W. Berkowsky, Elizabeth Yost, Vicki Winstead, and William Anderson.
2014. “Getting Grandma Online: Process, Outcomes, and Challenges Associated with
Conducting a 5 Year ICT and Quality of Life Randomized Controlled Trial in Assisted and
Independent Living Communities.” Assisted Living Interest Group Symposium presented at the
annual meeting of the Gerontological Society of America, November 6, Washington DC.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2014. “The Interaction between Internet Use and Functional Limitations
in Predicting Depressive Symptoms in Older Adults.” Presented at the annual meeting of the
American Sociological Association, August 18, San Francisco, CA.
Berkowsky, Ronald W., Shelia R. Cotten, and Vicki Winstead. 2014. “Tech Tension: Examining ICT
Use, Technology-Related Work Enhancements/Detriments, and Stress.” Presented at the 14th
International Conference on Social Stress Research, June 8, Vancouver, Canada.
CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS (CONTINUED)
Berkowsky, Ronald W., Shelia R. Cotten, Elizabeth Yost, and Vicki Winstead. 2014. “Impacts of

Communities.” Presented at the annual meeting of the Southern Sociological Society, April 3,
Charlotte, NC.
Cotten, Shelia R., William Anderson, Elizabeth Yost, Vicki Winstead, and Ronald W. Berkowsky.
2013. “You Don’t Mess with Bingo: Recruitment and Retention of Technology Intervention
Study Participants from Independent and Assisted Living Communities.” Presented at the

Cotten, Shelia R., Ronald W. Berkowsky, Vicki P. Winstead, William A. Anderson, Elizabeth A. Yost,
and Brandi McCullough. 2013. “Scaling the Wall: Decreasing the Digital Divide in Assisted and
Independent Living Communities.” Presented at the annual meeting of the American
Sociological Association, August 12, New York, NY.
Cotten, Shelia R., Vicki P. Winstead, William A. Anderson, Ronald W. Berkowsky, Elizabeth A. Yost,
and Brandi McCullough. 2013. “Internet Usage and Connection with the Social World among
Older Adults in Assisted and Independent Living Communities.” Accepted to the 20th IAGG
World Congress of Gerontology and Geriatrics, June 23-27, Coex, Seoul, South Korea.
Winstead, Vicki P., Elizabeth A. Yost, Shelia R. Cotten, William A. Anderson, Ronald W. Berkowsky,
and Sarah Khalidi. 2013. “Why Does Grandma Never Answer the Phone? Increasing Quality of
Life Outcomes Through Activities in Continuing Care Communities.” Presented at the annual
meeting of the Southern Gerontological Society, April 6, Charlotte, NC.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2012. “Examining Internet Use, Social Integration, and Psychological
Well-Being in a Cohort of Older Adults.” Presented at the annual meeting of the Gerontological

Cotten, Shelia R., Ronald W. Berkowsky, Will Anderson, Brandi McCullough, Vicki Winstead, and
Elizabeth Yost. 2012. “Going Online: Examining Types of Internet Use Among Older Adults.”
Presented at the annual meeting of the Gerontological Society of America, November 15, San
Diego, CA.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2012. “Examining Internet Use, Social Integration, and Psychological
Well-Being in a Cohort of Older Adults.” Presented at the annual meeting of the UAB Center for
Aging, October 16, Birmingham, AL.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2012. “When You Just Can’t Get Away: Exploring the Use of ICTs in
Facilitating Negative Work/Home Spillover.” Presented at the annual meeting of the American
Sociological Association, August 20, Denver, CO.
Cotten, Shelia R., William A. Anderson, Ronald Berkowsky, Elizabeth Yost, and Vicki Winstead.
2012. “Can Information and Communication Technology Usage by Older Adults Decrease
Stress, Social Isolation, and Loneliness? Results from a Randomized Trial.” Presented at the

CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS (CONTINUED)
Berkowsky, Ronald W. and Shelia Cotten. 2012. “Using Computers and the Internet in Assisted

Presented at the annual meeting of the Southern Sociological Society, March 22, New Orleans,
LA.
Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2012. “When You Just Can’t Get Away: Exploring the Use of ICTs in

Berkowsky, Ronald W. 2011. “Internet Use and Psychological Well-Being in Older Adults.”
Presented at the annual meeting of the American Sociological Association, August 22, Las Vegas,
NV.
Anderson, William, Amanda M. Warr, Shelia Cotten, Ronald W. Berkowsky, Vicki Winstead, and
Elizabeth Yost. 2011. “The Role of Social Support and Social Networks in Older Adults’

April 8, Jacksonville, FL.
Winstead, Vicki, Elizabeth A. Yost, Shelia R. Cotten, William A. Anderson, Amanda M. Warr, and
Ronald W. Berkowsky. 2010. “You Can Teach an Old Dog New Tricks: A Qualitative Analysis

Birmingham, AL.
Winstead, Vicki, Elizabeth A. Yost, Shelia R. Cotten, William A. Anderson, Amanda M. Warr, and
Ronald W. Berkowsky. 2010. “You Can Teach an Old Dog New Tricks: A Qualitative Analysis

Winstead, Vicki, Elizabeth Yost, Amanda Warr, Ronald W. Berkowsky, William Anderson, and
